- Making strong connections within both a college campus and high school environment

- Opportunity for virtual advising
- Full-time employee benefits (health, dental, vision, and life insurance) as long as you opt-in
cons:
- Fresh administrative staff, but this could easily be neutral or positive depending on how you look at it
- Meager annual salary on top of getting paid on a monthly basis
- Unforeseen events/occurrences depending on which high school you are assigned to

pros: everything is really really great

review_title: Still enjoy position and experiences, concerned about mission and future.
pros: Small liberal arts college with a collegial environment that allows for flexibility to experiment and explore. I have enjoyed working closely with our students. Of course, I am in a position where I can work with select students, so that helps promote my positive attitude.
cons: Not always a clear path about our college mission or direction. Leadership at various levels is uneven. No room for growth, but who gets into academics for growth or money. Lately the college can feel more like a country club, which fosters the noted coddling of students. This can be a real shame, since the college has made great strides to attract students from various countries, regions, backgrounds and economic classes. That diversity can seem squandered, as students too easily wander off to comfort zones.

job_title: Visiting Assistant Professor in Lancaster, PA
pros: Much more supportive (in salary and benefits) and professional than other employment I've had in academia. A lot of academic positions in the humanities are very poorly supported lately, and after teaching at a couple different colleges and universities this was the first time I felt treated like a valued professional. Fair salary, overall good colleagues. Of course there are a few bad apples everywhere but the norm seemed to be that people cared about doing well at their jobs.
cons: Small school. It can be nice if you like that atmosphere--easier to meet people, and sort of a nice "small-town feel" in how they do things (i.e. they sent out an email seeing if anyone had a tug of war rope that could be borrowed for freshman orientation, rather than immediately going out to buy one). But as a small undergrad school it's less stimulating than a big university.

pros: The staff and community of the College.
cons: Unless you are faculty it is a sweatshop. Moral is low, staff asked to work long hours for very little pay or merit increases. The benefits use to be very good but healthcare has gone up considerably.

review_title: Good place to work but not much opportunity for advancement
pros: Overall great work environment, excellent benefits and vacation time. Very respectful climate. Flexible environment in respect to work life environment.
cons: Salary increases are less than cost of living regardless of stellar work reviews. Not very much opportunity to advance or move forward, especially for admin workers of mid level professional staff. Have to move to another  college to advance career.

job_title: Circulation Desk Assistant in Lancaster, PA
pros: I am working at Franklin&Marshall College as a student at the Circulation Desk in the Martin Library of the Sciences. Everyone is very nice and the work is pretty straightforward.
cons: Working as a student only gets you minimum wage salary, which in PA equates to only $7.25/hour.

pros: The people are very nice and cooperative. I was a student worker here for 3 years and I liked every position I held. The college is very organized, professional, and caring.
cons: Some of the offices have a lot to do so they can be high stress areas.
